column1: The Pico running MicroPython talks to a computer via a USB serial protocal called UART. There's a variety of programs which can do this for you, from very lightweight, purpose-built applications to larger multipurpose software you may already be familiar with. I've only chosen software that works on all major platforms (Windows, Linux, Mac), but there's other great options available for specific platforms as well
Before anything else, take a look at the offical Raspberry Pi Pico's Getting Started page for setting up MicroPython.

Most Python IDEs will allow for MicroPython development, though some don't specifically support it. If you have one you really love, you can keep using it.
column4: No matter what, you'll need software that can perform serial communcation with your Pico. This allows you to upload Python files and access the Pico's on board REPL (Python's interactive command loop).

column1: If you're familiar with the Arduino IDE, then you might be hoping for a MicroPython IDE that lets you do both 1 and 2; develop and upload code directly from the same application. Well good news, many IDEs can also do communcation/upload for you, so you just need one program! The most popular IDE by far is Thonny (see below).

IDEs with built in communication - Applications designed for development of Python code, which also can be used to access REPL on the board and upload Python files. Much bigger than the devoted communication software below, but everything is integrated for you. You do not need other communication software if you use one of these (such as rshell).
